Bought this book on a whim at the Philly AIDS Thrift Shop (90% off all books? yes, please). I read it in its entirety in a 16 hour journey from Paris to Philly. Needless to say, the book definitely helped those hours fly by.I really enjoyed this book. I especially liked that it takes place in Philadelphia and gave a good insight about how slavery was viewed in the US, and especially PA, in 1855. I would definitely recommend this book to anyone who is interested in historical fiction or to anyone who enjoys learning about Philly's past.

Two stars - it was okay. The story itself was good, but it got lost in the telling. For exemple, I found myself frustrated when, after Ginnie finally climbed out from beneath the blankets and straw in the wagon to breathe freely, the narration turned toward the Quick family. These were Ginnie's first real moments of freedom, but the author chose this moment to introduce them. I might add that there were so many members in this family that I could never quite keep them all straight, apart from Harriet and perhaps Manny and Della. I wonder if there wouldn't have been a better way to introduce them, perhaps fewer at a time instead of all at once.I also feel that Ginnie's pain at leaving Bennie behind wasn't given sufficient recognition. I would have thought her first move, once free, would have been to ask the members of the Underground Railroad about bringing him north. As it is, I almost feel that the book's title was not justified, although I did like the ending. It was realistic, instead of perfect.

I'm about half way through, and it's not as good as I really wanted it to be. But then I wonder, do I hold historical novels about slavery to higher standards? How does a person write really well about this enormous traumatic injustice that went on for centuries? And I hate to say it, but how does one write about slavery after Toni Morrison wrote about slavery? That said, I just think it's thin. I don't much care about the romance plot. I want Mercer to be happy, but I don't want to read about that. I want to learn more about life and about what it means to "pay" a child for freedom. Then I think, am I no different from all those white abolitionist ladies who only want to hear about drama and heartache? Why can't I just let Mercer find love and happiness? Finished a few days ago. Disappointing. I don't feel like it did the necessary work to earn the ending, which could have been much more moving if that narrative arc were more carefully crafted.Sigh. Finished: a resounding meh.

The story was compelling, the characters were not, the writing difficult to read. The text came off as being preachy, which is fine if that is what the book is supposed to do. Although this is a difficult subject to write about, I have read other books on the same topic and come away feeling as though I was a part of the book. I know I was supposed to care about all of these characters, but they weren't written for us to know them, only to read about them.

Although slow at times, I found this book to be filled with beautiful prose, vivid characters, and striking statements of truth that opened my eyes in new ways, as well as a lot more historical back-ground on this time period and area of slavery; Lorene Cary certainly did do her research, and has a talent for sliding historical facts into the story without you really realizing it (until your Humanities teacher makes you look the stuff up). I definitely recommend it.

I loved the beginning of the book, but it quickly turned into a story about the Quick Family and not the child Mercer left behind. If this in fact based on a true story, I would like to know if Mercer ever found Bennie.
This is a very good book. I like this author and I recommend it.

Reading something that you don’t really enjoy can be hard for many people. But sometimes there’s something about the book that keeps a person reading it. It could be because of something they heard about the book or just curiosity. Very few people does this because when they aren’t very interested, they give up on the book.From interesting to suspenseful to boring to interesting again, Lorene Cary’s novel “The Price of a Child” tells about a family who was able to become free. After many years, Virginia Pryor and her children was finally able to be free from her master and slavery with the help of Philadelphia’s Vigilance Committee. With freedom and new lives, a new name had to be made for Virginia (Mercer Gray) as well as new relationships and responsibilities as she becomes a speaker on the abolition circuit. When reading “The Price of a Child”, I was really interested in reading the book at first because there was so much going on. You wanted to know what happened in the past and what would happen next. But as I kept reading the book, the interest started to die down causing me to read the book less and less. However, I never stop reading the book because I still wanted to know what was going to happen to Mercer and her kids. I wanted to know how the book was going to end. And as I kept reading, the book started to get interesting again because unpredicted events started to happen. I never enjoyed reading books that had to do with slavery or history in general because I’m not a big history fan. Even though a book is fiction, I still can’t find myself reading it. That’s why this book was a challenge for me to read. I’ve never read a book like this on my own will before and that’s why I decided to read it. I wanted to read something new for a change. And even though I found the book interesting in the beginning and ending, I can’t come to say that this book was my overall favorite because lost my attention. I would catch myself reading the book but not knowing what was happening so I would have to read the pages over again. I would recommend this book to someone who enjoys historical events. Someone who is crazy about history and not looking for extra excitement. And those who don’t really like history, I wouldn’t recommend this book because they probably wouldn’t enjoy as much like I did. But if someone wanted to challenge themselves, I would say this book would the one especially if you and history don’t get along. “The Price of a Child” was a book that I thought I wasn’t going to like and I was right. And for now on I am going to continue to read books that fits my interest but will also read books that is out of my reading comfort to challenge myself even more.

This book takes place in 1855 and follows a slave and mother of 3 named Ginnie. Growing up as an educated slave, her owner Jackson Pryor always treated her well and liked her, he liked her so much that he is the father of her three children. The novel starts out with Jackson only allowing Ginnie to bring her two oldest children with him and her as they travel north. Once in Philadelphia, Ginnie and the kids managed to escape from Jackson. They then had to go into hiding with help from the Quick's family who are involved in the underground railroad. Changing her name to Mercer, she had to leave her children to go hide in New York where she began to be involved in speaking out about slavery rights. Eventually, she came back to Philadelphia to her kids and fell in love with a married man, Tyree but in the end they cannot be together but she is given money from him, almost enough to buy her child back left in Virginia. I found this book to be good but it is for people who enjoy history but do not need interesting events to happen. This did a good job of showing what America was like during the time of slavery and their struggles.It could get boring and was a sad book but I would still recommend it.

In this book "The Price of a Child", the main character Ginnie Pryor is a woman with two children who are trying to start a new life by trying to get away from a man named Jackson. They go through out the whole state of Pennsylvania to find a place where they could stay permanently. Ginnie later on in the story changes her name to Mercer, goes to court to become a free woman from Jackson Pryor. After that, Ginnie and Tyree start to have feelings for each other and try to begin a relationship until he finds out that his family doesn't have any more money. Mercer at the end continues on to find a stable a life with her family, and she moves on from Tyree to go to West Chester, PA.What I liked about this book was the fact that it was really compelling and interesting. It pulls you in to read more and more of the book to find out what happens next. What also makes this book really good is that it is a book based off of real events, which makes the book even more credible for the reader becoming interesting in the book.I would recommend this book to people who are interested in historical books. I would also recommend this book to the people who are interested in books that are suspenseful.

Masterfully written, beautifully structured, and gracefully portrayed, The Price of a Child is a literary stroke of genius. For readers who enjoy historical fiction set during antebellum period, this novel will not disappoint. The novel opens during the year of 1855, when Lorene Cary introduces the heroin character of Ginnie Pryor, a Virginia plantation slave, and her crusade to seek freedom. Cary also brilliantly addresses Philadelphia’s Underground Railroad history by intriguingly basing the character of Ginnie Pryor on the actual life of a gallant Philadelphian slave woman. An intriguing page turner, Cary accomplishes the feat of writing about a troubling part of American history, in an adept manner.

This was a selection for One Book, One Philadephia, an event that encourages the entire city to read the same book. It tells the story of Mercer Gray, a black woman living in Philadelphia circa 1855. Constitutional issues surrounding race and justice are part of our nation's struggle.I read this book 9 years ago and just stumbled upon the calendar of events booklet that promoted this incredible undertaking by the city of Philadelphia. Applause! Applause! What a magnificent idea to bring a city together through reading a book. Unfortunately, due to the years that have passed, my memory is foggy of the story but I know that it was an interesting read.

This was my second reading. It was amazing. I really enjoyed the relationship between Mercer and Tyrene. Theirs was a relationship they could not pursue. 2009 #10: This was a really good story about the issues in the U.S. at the time when slavery was legal in the South but not the North. It dealt wit some interesting issues, like whether a mother could/should leave behind one child in slavery in order to escape with two of her other children. It also showed the white people in the North fawning over the escaped slaves from the South. While most of them still didn't believe the blacks should have equal rights, their help and funding was a big part of helping the slaves to escape.

Written from a realistic and forthright perspective, the story is about a young woman, enslaved first by one master, then, in freedom, used by another. The perspective allowed this reader to see how well-intentioned abolitionists carted freed slaves around as if they were a side-show, telling tales and showing scars in order to make a statement. Is a kind slave master that different from a stern and demanding abolitionist master? I think the author asked this question throughout the novel, with a detailed account of both. Great read from a new perspective...

This book was a pleasant surprise. Think a fictionalized account of Harriet Jacobs Life of a Slave Girl. In Price of a Child, Cary explores motherhood, slavery, and connection. I enjoyed the book and the themes it explored - particularly the way that Cary addresses classism and the divide between free blacks and former slaves. Overall I find the book hard to put down. It's definitely an unexpepected gem.

description: With Price of a Child--the story of Ginnie Pryor (cook, mistress and servant to a Virginia planter) and her struggle with slavery in 1855--Cary continues has created a work that elevates the reputation she created with Black Ice, her memoir which won her comparisons to Maya Angelou and Richard Wright. In a novel that examines the price of freedom and the value of a child's life, Price of a Child is "a stunning achievement...a deeply engrossing story.... Cary's impeccable research and seamless narrative carry us along" (Philadelphia Inquirer).
